Technically the Constitution say Congress can declare war, but they haven't done that since WWII. All others have been authorized military force by Congress. 

But some will and have argued that Congress authorizing the use of military force to invade another country, is enough to be considered a declaration of war.

Me personally, I don't see how you can send hundreds of thousands of troops to invade a country on the other side of the world, completely destroy their military, bombing every base they have, killing enemy combatant, dismantle their government, then occupy this country for two decades while you try to form a government of your making/will, and not be at war with this country/people. 

There was a court case on this Doe V Bush which basically says that the AUMF against Iraq was Congress authorizing a war. 

You can't do everything but use the actual word "war". Congress passed a law that both authorizes and legally compels a President to initiate military action against a sovereign nation, that is war. 

We had multiple Presidents across multiple Congress's, with all of them calling them a War. 

They all for the most part referenced it as a War, they even said the 2001 AUMF was consistent with the "War Powers Resolution".
